div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

div.head: Egypt and Turkey
div.p: The Tabah frontier incident was not a mere accident, says the author of an interesting article in the current Contemporary Review," but the first step in great contemplated movement which was to culminate in the Sultan resuming possession of Egypt. It arose out of the Asistic hopes that were stimulated and encouraged by the Japanese success, It seams extraordinary and almost incomprehensible that the success of England's ally in the Par Bast should encourage the Sultan to attack England in the Near East. But those who were living in the country daring the war perceived that the keen in- terest with which the Turks followed the struggle was not merely because thay felt that they themselves were gaining, and. thas Japan was their champion. The Sultan was flattered, quite willingly as is said, by Mollahs from Arabia and similar hangers-on at the Palace into the belief that he had but to enter into Egypt, and England would put and dared not resist, Doubtless they quoted the fact, which is mentioned by gossip, in Turkey, that the English in Egypt were not afraid of Mohamedans that they have given op their Sunday and adopted the Mohamedan day of rest ; that they dared not act on their own prio- ciples in religion, but tried to win the favour of the Faithfal by abandoning what their false faith taught. Now perhaps gossip will tell how, when English officers were hastled by a village mob, they gave op their weapons — the last disgrace ot soldier—and ran like help- less sheep. A Mohamedan country cannot be held by conduct like that.A Christian Power which makes Friday its day of rest is discredited as much as soldiers who hand over their weapons to assailantee. No one can ever win the respect of Mohamedans by forewear- ing the principles of his religion ; he merely earn their contempt. Courage they respect : faithfalness to principle they admire: pliability they despise as the character of the Eastern Christians and of the English in Egypt. Responsible ministers did not entertain such mistaken ideas, but they have little or no power in Turkey : for the real influence that moves Turkish action in all things great and small resides not at the Ports but in the Palace. And officials knew that there had been, much tampering with the Egyptian Mohamedans, and believed, as all did in Turkey, that thie tampering had been very successful, Many flattered themselves and the Sultan, as it is paid, with the idea that his invading army would attract the mass of Mohamedan Egypt to the cause of the Faith, It is small wonder, in such surrdendings, that the Sultan has come to believe much of what he was told, and that his opinion as to his overwhelming and irresistible power has dis- torted his outlook. It is declared by some people that he is so impressed with his great- ness and might as to be hardly of forming a sound opinion on matters where his dignity seems to be involved. There are among the officials of the Palace Turks who are wiser and better informed ; but every one of them knows that if his opinion should be asked, it would be as much as his life was worth to express his real opinion or say any- thing except what the Sultan desired. And so every person told him that "the master of a million of soldiers and Lord of the Faithful could do what be pleased in Egypt." The extreme unwillingness on the Sultan's part to admit formally anything that he dislikes lends additional emphasis to the issue of the Tabah incident. The Saltan had never before admitted in any way the right of England to speak for Egypt. That was the reason why, when a British sbip tried to treat with some Turkish official near the Mediter- ranean end of the boundary claimed, the Turks would not speak to any Englishman, but insisted on having an Egyptian official sent on shore to state the Egyptian claim. It was only the fear of those big English ships hovering somewhere in the unknown between the Piraeaus the Dardanelles, that impelled the Sultan at last to yield ; and the admission which cost bim the soreat pang probably was that England and English ships stood for Egypt and spoke for Egypt. That admission on his part was the most important fact in the incident. A few miles of desert were of no consequence in themselves, but the moral effect on a considerable part of the population of Egypt was of great importance, and some echo of the facts may even reach the care of the Mohamedans outside of Turkey.

div.head: EGYPT AND SCANDINAVIA.
div.p: 'THE MIXED TRIBUNALS.
IMPORTANT NEGOTIATIONS.
. (Gazette's Special Service. )

London, Monday afternoon. Sir Malcolm Mollwraith bas arrived at Copenhagen on » visit to Scandinavia. in connection with the futore nominations of jadges to the Mixed Tribanals in Bgypt. It is considered that the object of this visit of the Jadicial Adviser to the Danish capital is to obtsin the assurance of the Danish Government to the new jedicial reforms con- templated by Lord Cromer in reference to the statos of subjects of Baropean Powers in Egypt. It is probable that Sir Maloolm Moliwraith will proceed to Scandinavia in order to discuss with the Swedish and Nor- wogian Governments certain difficulties which have arisen in Egypt owing to the political separation of these two countries and the constitution of Norwsy ss separate and in- dependent Kingdcm. Hitherto Mr. Borchgtev- ink, the Procoreur Général at the Mixed Coortr, and Jodge Montan have collectively represented the onited Sweden and Norway, bat io view of altered political circumstances some new arrangement will have to be made. It is covsidered at Chri that Mr. Borchgreviok, who is of Not birth, will continae to represent Norway aud Judge Montan, who is a Swede, will rspresent bis own country.

div.head: ATTAKA QUARRIES.
div.p: RAILWAY LINE INAUGURATED.
(From ovr own Correspondent)

Suez, Monday. Messrs, C J. Wills and Sons, contractors for. the new harbour works at Port Said, insagarat- ed yesterday morning at the Attaka moantain at Scez(from where theyprocare the stone),their naw railway line. from the quay to the moun- 'tain, a distance of abont 3-miles... Aboot 25 guests were invited by Mr. Shalley, obief engineer in charge, and Messrs, G. Lezzerini and Co., the local sgents, for. the 'occasion. The togboat Ellispondos was kindly-pot at the disposal of the guests by Mr. Mavrokefallos, which reached ths Attaka landing stage at 9.80 am. Shortly after. the train conveyed the gaents op the mountain to' view the works, and Mr, Soott, assistant superintendent. engi- neer, very kindly tock the party round, and bed several mines blown op'in their presence, and saberquently péreonally drove the train down to, Mr. Shalley's residence, where » most excellent Ianch was served, at the end of which several hearty toasts were exchanged. Later in the afternoon, s very successful fishing trip was arranged, and finally the party landed at Port Tewfik at 7 p.m. after a most enjoyable picnic, which will be remembered for a long time by all who were present.

Messrs, C. J. Wills and Sons have obtained the contract for dredging the Suez roads, which will commence shortly. I understand that the 'same firm have proposed to the Government to dredge the oreek leading to Suez, and all concerned hope that the Government will 'accord them the contract, the oresk in 'question is how impassable at low tide, which is » great drawback to commerce.

div.head: THE DENISHWAL AFFAIR.
div.p: The ablication by the \Poreign Office of the official\doasier" relating\to the Denishwai Laffait lesdsto some oommentiin the London 'Pros. The "Daily Chronicle" ssys :— Qne of the defending coonsel orged that "these persons were living in » 'milieo,' which which bad influenced their actions," and pleaded for clemency on that ground. The argoment, it seems to os, might: well be tarn- ed in the other direction. If the existing "milieu" is sooh as to encourage determined attacks on British officer, there was the more resson for giving a stern lesson.
The "Globe" remarks-—

The "dossier" most emphatically confirms the deliberate and intensified character of the ootrage, and ,the justice of the sentences which were meted out, It will probably sur- prise even most of those persons in this country who followed fairly closely the con- temporary accounts of this sinister affair, to observe, from Msjor Pine-Coffin's detailed evidence, {he premeditated and sustained malignity of the attack. made by these Bgyp- tian villagers. 'The sffait, which ended in the death of. one British officer, and grave injnries to several otherr, was as far as pos- sible from soch a sudden outbreak of ferocity, based upon s misunderstanding, x has some- times led to melancholy tragedies among porely savage peoples. The attack was care- fally prepared and arranged by the represen- tative people of the village, aud the grave and fatal injoriés sostained by the party of officers were distributed over-s considerable space of time, allowing for ample opportunity of con- sideration. Avy candid reading of the evi- dence now fally available will dispose in the completest manner of the attacks upon the homanity and jastice of the British authorities which bave been msde in relation to this affair, both in this coastry and outside it. The most convincing point of all is in the character of the speeches which were made by the counsel for thé defence. As is pointed oat by the Consal-General at Cairc, these three advocates are among the ablest repre- sentatives of the Egyptian Bar, and two of them had volonteered their services spontan- sously. We may be perfectly sure thst if it bad been is way possible to pat thé case of the native aggressors'in s fayouravle light; the eloquence of the defending counsel would have compassed it. Their failare to do so is convincing. proof of the i testable nature of the evidence, and of the jastics of the sentences.

div.head: CRIME IN UPPER EGYPT.

A certain Mohamed el Kholy cf Amberkal village, Bl Derr marker, recently rejected asa fuitor for the hand of(bis deceased brother's widow; who was seoretly temarried Inst week. nen the news was divhjged Mohsmed el Kholy proceeded to. the hon: the woman,on whom be fixed the responsibility for the secret marrisge, and attempted to marder him by shooting. Unsuocessfal with his first . weapon, he drew a knife and stabbed the man several times in the abdomen. From this point s family fight commenced, the first assailant being shot in the head by » cousin of the woonded man, and one of the former's cousins then broke the latter's right arm. It is feared that abdominal wounds of the women's nephew will prove fatal.

div.head: THE SINAI BOUNDARY.
div.p: TURKEY'S OPPOSITION.

The Jerusalem deat of » London contemporary, writing under date of the let inst, says :—The position of affairs at Bi Rafeh, as_regards the delimitation of the Tarco- Egyptian frontier, remains unchanged. The disinclination of the Tarkish delegates to agree to a» straight line trom a point three miles west of El Akabs to Bi Rafeh, which had slresdy bean acospted by the Porte cn May 14, in delaying a final settlement of the ques- tion and the retarn of the Aoglo-Ezyptian Commissioners to Cairo from Rafeb, where they bave been camping "for more than two months.

It appears that the Turkish Commissioners, acting onder instroctions from Constantinople, are endeavooring to find plausible objections to a straight line, in order to upset the agreement refarred to, aod with that object they have incited the obiefs of the Arab tribes under Tarkish ralp bordering the frontier to sign = protest against the new line, which the English surveyors already marked "ont, alleging 'that the water-springs at Magdabé, Ain Gadis, Bl.Goseimelb, and El Mayen were always situated within their territory on the Torkish side, and that they have for centories past drawn their water sopply trom those localities, The chieftains warn the. Torkish anthorities against being out off from those water courses, and threaten to cause trouble if they and their followers are. placed at the morcy of the Egyptian Bedains for their water, The Turkish officials at the soeeded in obtain- ing @ declaration signed by some of the chiefs of the tribes on the Bgyptian side oorroborat- ing tatement of the Bedoins onder Turk- ish jarisdiction.

div.head: THE NILE FLOOD.
div.p: There is very prospect, of the Nile keepiog absolutely satisfactory, and quite sofficient for basin irrigation in Upper Egypt. The state of the levels gives rise to no anxiety as regards the safety of the banks in Lower Baypt. From the poiat of view of the summer crop and the flood orop it ought to be an excellent year.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: The weekly plagae bulletin issued by the Poblic Health , Department reports the noti- fication of seven cases throughout Egypt last week, four of which occurred at Alexandria, two at Saez, and one in Bani-Suef district. Bince the 1st of Janoary there have been in all 453 cases reported, as compared with 256 and '196 doring the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904 respedtively."
A European the Hamamil quarter was admitted into ria scffering from j babonio plague yesterday, and two cases and ; one death are reported from Suez.

div.head: THE PYRAMIDS MURDER.
div.p: Farther details are to hand concerning the marder which was Gommitted on Wednesday last near the Pyramids. It .appeare that Abou Samat was a nezir in the service of Soliman Bey Nassif, who was having an artesian wall sank on bis estates; and Nicolas Mogabgab, the murderer, a Syrisn, was super- intending the work. |

Abou Samat examined the accounts of the overseer and found faalt with them ; in faot, he treated Nicolas Mogsbgab like « thief. This enraged the overseer, and the argoment became so heated that the ghsflir intervened aod Aboo Samat -to sleep in the wakil's shed. He rose to go, but before he had gone-two paces Nicolas Mogabgab faced him, and fired three times, killing him on the spot. The ghaffir ronning op, was strack by the fourth cartridge. The homicide made off. 'The sheikhs of the neighbouring villages were soon on the scene, as well as the police, who opened an eogairy. %

On the following gtternoon Mogabgab enter- ed the offices "of Soliman Bey, and demanded money from' the oashier, who replied that be had none ; he probably intended to kill the wakil also. arderer is still at large. Mogabgab was an ex-volunteer with the Boglish Army in the Transvaal daring the war. He suffers from reurasthenia,and it is probable that the charges levelled at him by Aboo Gamat 20 wrought opon his nerves as to drive him to desperation.

div.head: THE NATIONAL BANK.
div.p: THE PROPOSED CONVERTION.

Our statement that the negotiations had been completed for converting the National Bank of Bgypt into a State Bank has been misconstrued by some of-our readers. The faot.ia that the preliminary negotiations be tween the Bgyptian Government and the Governor of the National Bank of Egypt have beon brought to a satisfactory termination, bat of course itwill be necessary that the result of these negotiations should be accepted by the board of directors and also by the share- holders of the bank at an extraordinary geve- ral mesting, which will be summoned when the vsoal sammer exodas is over, and "toute Egypte" ia back again.

div.head: STATE RAILWAY ENGINES.
div.p: The average namber of engines amountsto 520, of which an average of 118 engines (in- cloding seven narrow gaoge locomotives of the old Port Ssid-Ismailia line) have been standing and undergoing repairs, leayiog an average of 402 in eervice. Of these 89-have been employed on shunting, and 313 on regular train servicd, 'The new engines received during the year con; sisted of the powerfol compound express en- gines of the "Atlantic" type constracted by the "Ateliers de Cail" in France ; ten four-coupled bogie passenger engines from. Me: Hepsebel & Son, Cassel ; nine six-cobpled js engines and one six-coupled passenger engine from the Pranoo-Belge Company, and thirty six-coupled goods engines from the North British Locomot- ive Company. The six engines scrapped doring the year wore all six-coupled goods engines. | The average age of locomotives in 1905 wen 14 years, as against 15 yearsin 1904.

"Phe total engine kilometrage ran in 1905 was 19,641,66! against 17,637,462 in 1904, which gives an incresse of 2,104,201 kilo. metres, or 18 %. The avorage kilometrage per engine has been. increased. from 55,925 in 1904 to 56,931 in 1905.
'The number'of engines fitted with the anto- matio vacuom brake,. ap to 81st December, 1905, was 231, as against .169 at the end of 1994, Besides these, 16 engines 'were fitted with steam brakes.
Daring the year, 187 engines underwent thorough repairs, and 452 light repairs, giving ® total of 639 engines passing through the shope. No engines were entirely renewed.

Les Egyptiens h-issent ies Angisis parce que ceuxi lear ont ravi le bien le plas précieax, Vindépendance, ils baissent les Frangsis qai les ont-yenda par leur récant accord, ils baissent lee Grees ot les Lersélites qai les exploitent, ils n'aiment pas les étrangers en général parc: 'qo'ils sont psisus et ils ont mataellement une sympatbie tells que s'il arrive 4 l'on d'eox (d'étre tué on blese¢, méme par accident, par an @tranger, ils s6 souldyent en masse ot frap- pent iudistinctement ooupables et innocents pourva .qa'ils soient étrangers. Mais le fana- tisme hideox' qu'on reproche aux Egyptien c'est on Barope qa'il faut le chercher. Le senti- ment qai anime les Bgyptiens n'est qa'an patriotieme éolairé.

—7Bans-donte les Egyptieos siment Ja 'Tur quis ;"fls siment méme les Tores ot ils vont josqu'h regretter les Mamelouks. Cet amour va mémé'si loia que le Saltan ayant voula récem meat s'emparer d'on simple lambean de désert fort importsot.ao..point.de.so0-stratégique, majssans valecr commerciale, les Egyptiens D'ontipaa bésité ds lear eoosentir ce sacrifice oe sont Jes Anglais qui s'y sont opposés. — Téant}qne la France » géoé |'Angleterre en Egypte, nous sotres Egyptiens nous étious precqoe sassi contents que les Allemands ; cette latte diplomatique noas smusait énormé- ment; pons {aisionsméme de l'hamoar & ce sujet en éorivant qn'sprés toat cs ce mar- chait.pas mal avec les Anglais ; |'Egypte pros- pérait. Oppenbeim, mais ea condoite pendant I'sffsire de Tabah m'a dégooté. Ans nous 6 comptons plas qos snr nos propres foroey pons ralevonir spjets du Sultan.

Sortes espoirs d'indépendanca We l'Egypte. -Le seul moyen pour l'Egypte de devenir indépendante c'est de se faire reconqnérir par Is Tarqnie. Ceci expliqre notre'attitade dans effaire do Tabab. Plas le Solten p:end d'avan tage scr nons et plos nous spprochons de Vindépendance. Co banqust, c'est moi qui I'si ordohné & mes partisans. J'si préparé sir |'indépendance de I'Egypte an discours qui fera seasation, et qni finira de me placer 4 Ia téta de ce joarna lisme égyptien dont ja snis, n'en déplaive an Journal da Caire etau Cheikh Aly Youssef, le chef incontesté. Je ne parle pas des nov- vesux abonnements ac Lewa et dea potits cadeanx que jo redevrai k cette oocasion. Ces réponses terminées, comme on s'appré tait & loi en poser d'autres, l'esprit se retira en toute hi'e, en.feappant un coup sec, . C'est da moins ce que m'expliqaa mon gaide. Faut il vous diré qae-malgré toate la confiance que j'ai dans le Dr. D., je 'ne sais pas encore oon- verti na spiritisme. Eo tout cas, o'sst bien Ja premidre et. deraidre fois. que je passe ms poit A écoater ua patriote égyptien. Agréer, Monsiear le Directear, mes saluta- tions. Gat.

div.head: NIGHT PICTURE.
div.p: BY ARTHUR S. DELANY

The one redeeming featore in the boildioga of Port Said is the balcony. If the soul is weary of the hollowness of 'the life below let it prompt the tired body to repose, and reflect from the baloony's height upon the general aspect beneath. Here one can draw the essence of things. The moving homanity list- lersly wandering through an acacia-stodded street strikes one as pawns in that mystic game called life, and in the fast fading light we msy look upon the fringe of the Mediter- ranean lying subject at oor feet A wondrous Pesce seems to permeste all the atmosphere, aod the whole of our being. Away from homanity's reach we are at liberty to think : to give birth to thoughts onadolterated by the gaudy tinsel of the town, for to as, as to most peoplr, solitude often spells peace. Milton atrock the trae note, when hé said :-— "Solitude sometimes is best society, And short retirement argues sweet return." Bat as yet we do not wish to anticipate the retarn. We are lost in the glories of an Oriental saneet. Here is « blend of colour uneqaalled in its glowing beanty. Against this reverential blsze the moezzin is calling from the minaret his exhortation to. prayer. His voice from where we recline cannot be heard, bat we koow, well enough, the express- ion, Hard by some Mohamedan obeying the dictates of bis religion is performing evola- tions, Alleah, ill Allab, aod « yashmak horties slong near where the ses licks the hot sand. A comparison with former experiex the basis of homan happiness. We have known London —that great pitiless city which holds compassion for no man. We have almost cried, as Charles Lamb did, with joy at the thooght of so moch life. We have sipped the oop to the brim,.sod observed the failores in life's battle, as well as those who bave achieved sacoesss,and when sick at heart have withdrawn to find rest snd relaxation faraway by some winding stream, near the old, old hills, or in the solitude of the valley, but the recovery never appeared to possess that completeness, which oor balcony offers in perhsps the most maligned placs upon the globe. %

It is dark now, and no sounds fret the silence, save the weird bom, which speaks of some ship being coaled. The restless tide of life is always on the flow at Port Said. Ships come, and go. Day and night, right and day. Is it possible for life to present anything more grot-eque, than the sight of the homan ants ranning bither and thither to » ship with their baskets of coal, to the accompaniment of a chant which reaches oor ears so weird s hom! These diminative creatares are the personification of coal dast, and as the light from the flambeaux throws ont their forms in | relief one might i ine that the water bad split in twain,and Hell breathed forth a sample j ot her wyriads. Yet they have souls. Souls which, like their longs, must be impregnated with coal. For their desth is coal. It in| always coal for thew.

While the depleted bunkers are being reple- nished, the passengers have joined in the night life of the town. There is something repulsive in the continental idea—to the Englishman— of sitting over the social g'sss in the arcades. which face all the refreshment halls, drinking in fall view of the passers-by, but it incréases oar present happinesr, and adds joy to the! exiled life to recreate visions of cross-beams, | oaken chairs, snd a goodly array of pewter, | that characterise the grand old English inn. A gentle wind is fanning vs, almost 4 zephyr. It recalls to memory s time, when the harsh winds of March were dead at home, and the | mscvy lilso plomes, snd the golden drops | of Iabarnom were swaying in the sunny breez, pear the summer's birth. So our toughts wander as we geze up to the sentinels of the night. The Lighthouse beams with an appall- ing regalarity-shior, pause, sod shine sgain over tha fsce of the waters, Now the eye anconecioanly follows a ship disappearing into the darkness of the night. Her /lights show us the band of Da Lessepe, with a digit point-| ing to the realisation of bis mighty enterpriee, | and we follow ontil one by one the lights are lost in the beyond. It teaches the vanity of the homan wish.

"And is this all? Can reason do no more Than bid me shun the deep, and dread the shore! Sweet Moralist ! Afloat om life's rough sea, The Christian has an art unknown to thee. He holds no parley with unmanly fears ; Where duty bids he confidently steres, Faces a thousand dangers at he r call, And trusting in his God, surmounts them all." The night bas grown old, the hovses seem asleep, acd our eyelids are heavy. The follies of earth are all bat gone,bat not quite extinct', for the reatleas homan ant still rans the plank } to the ship. An o-cssional arbagi rattles ov6r | the macadam, bot the halo of a lasting peice appears to bave descended ini luminous beauty over all.
We have lived in the memory of youth, imbibed the happicess. of the present, and 'fatarity seems to extend no further to-morrow. (ienerous, ger éroos natore to have endowed mau with sovsitility.

Signalman op post, lion at bottom."

div.head: MOSQUITO PLAGUE IN LONDON.
div.p: During the rodent spell of hot waather Lon- doners have been thevictims of s rather serious Plague of morqnitoes. Sach a plagoe has for some years past been of annasl reéoorrence at this season, bat this year the unasual heat seems to have bronght ont these uiwe'oome visitors in greater numbers than ever. Afd not only this,-bat their bites seem to be cnosvally viralent, for they bsve caused several people to be admitted to hospitals.

It is onlikely (*he "Westminster, G-setto" States) that the majority of these mosquitoes are natives. of our country. Large numbers of ths larve are brought over in.the stagoant water that accumulates in the holds of ships coming from moeqaito-ridden ports, and /heat-wave such as we have ben experiencing favours their farther development, jast as tropical plants are forced .io hothouses. The Port of London and the counties: bordering the moath of the Thames are usually infested—as is the case jast now ; while plagues of moequi. tos may always be expected to oconr near sesports rather than inland,

In many cases, however,ths so-called mosqai- toes are really species of gnats. The two general Anopheles (morqaito) and Culex (goat) may be readily distinguished by the fact that the former has spotted wings and a straight back, while the latter is bomp-backed and without spots. This distinction may appear ingeniously scientific, bat it is a practical one, and should enable the nervous man to determine which it js that ixfeste his neighbourhood, since i most probable that a certain species would occar in # certain area to the exclusion of others.

Goats and mosquitoes baves similar mode 01 lite. Every two days they teke « meal of baman blood, and retire to a dark corner to pass the interval in digestion. When bite with their shatp tobolar beaks théy inject at the
same time poisonous saliva, which in the case of certain species of morqaitd contains the patasites that caase malaria.

div.head: PRUSSIAN POLAND.
div.p: 'The Germsnisation of Protsian Poland isa scheme upon which the late Privoe Biemarck laid much atross, and one to which he lent his powerfal aid, bot neitber in his time nor since then bas the plan been a success. The Hakatist Leagoe bas jast held « congress at Marievbarg to disooss the question in all its bearings. The Hakatists is the name ofa league which was toonded in 1894 forthe purpose of transferring landed property in the Polish provinoss of Prussia from the Poles into those of the Germ it takes its odd name from the initials of its three foundere—Horren Hansemann, Kerme-

mann, and Tiedemann. The congress expressed | the desire that « Bill sboold be introdiced 'into the Prossian Parliament satborising the Commtssioners who are entrusted with the working of the law in the colonisation of the. eastarn provinces to expropriste the Polith holders of the Iand where they think fit' It is clear that some sdch bigh-baoded action will have to be taken if the Germans are not to be driven off the land, for nothing seems to stop the steady westward march of the Poles. It was stated at the congress that, thoogh Prossia bas' devoted no' less than twenty millions sterling in the purchase of estates and in settling German farmers on them, the | moont of land held by the Poles has enor- mouely increased in the Inst ten years. As soon as the German soloniats are given land io Prussian Poland they make haste to sell it to | the Poles at a high price. There seems to be only one thing to be done; and that is to | ponisb reverely those Germans who ell their land. Bot this is a course which the Prassians aaa unwilling to take.

div.head: THE ATTACK ON HELBAWI.
div.p: In an interview which recently took plac between s representative of "'Al-Watan" and Ibrabim Bey Helbawi, the latter, referring tc bia article entitled "The Hae avd Cry of the Impadent" referred toin "Al-Moayad" 'said that be bad written the same on his retarn voyage to Ezypt,bat that he bad postponed it publication for a few weeks. "In that artic'e" says Helbswi Bey "I did not touch upon any personal matters, but dealt with the present circamstances in general, pointing out the mirchisvous policy ofthe native Press, whose 'patriotiem' is mere folly which in no way forwards thi of the ocoantry. The mischigvous tone of « sectiper Of the verzacolar Pross hiss already been commented apon by Lord Cromer ssJikely to result 1, the suppression aj the liberty of both the Pr id the nation. The native 'jourpalists are to be excused for their perverted policy becanse the nation likes them to write to its satisfaction, while the Press is dependent apon the people. The backwardness and bisssed ideas of the people can be proved by the libellous papers being spread throoghoot Bgypt ; "Al-Him (the She Ass) osed to publish 25,(00 copies per week and it dealt only with such libel- lous aad defamatory topics. This, unforta- nately,proves the backwarduess of the nation." Reterring to the native papers which are attacking him,. Helbawi Bey said ; "Though 1 have the rightto take proceedings sgainst these papers [ do not care to do so because I still regret very moch that the majority of the Egyptians are of their opinion, and if I were to demand compensation from these papers, 1 woold be requiring the ponish- mont of their readers, of whom the woajority of the nation is composed, as both the ver. nacalar Press and their readers sro alike in being short-sighted in regard to conseq- uences."

div.head: PAPER FROM COTTON STALKS
div.p: The maanfacture of paper from the fibre of the cotton stalk is one of the latest inventions which are said to have passed the experimental stege. It in aseorted (says 'The World's Work") that all grades of paper, from the best form of linen to the lowest grade, can be manvfactured from ootton stalks. In addition to this, variety of wets such as: aloohol, ni trogen, material for ganootton ard smokeless powder, oan also be scored in paying quen- tities, Mills for the use of cotton stalks in that way may become general in the cotton-growing States.

It is estimated that on an area of land producing « bale of cotton at least one ton of stalks oan te gathered. Upon this basis, from 10,000,000 to 12,000,000 tons of raw material could be secured for the prodoction of paper, whic! would inoreass the value of the cotton orop of the Boathern States nearly £2,000,000.

div.head: AUVERGNE'S VOLCANOES.
div.p: In the light of so much that is taking place in other parts of the world, the question as to whetber there is any chance of the extinct yol- canoes of Auvergne again becoming dangerous possesses an onmistakable interest for French people. If the Pay de Ddme again began to make « rampos -it would undoubtedly create greater aproar than even separation or laicisa- tion laws, Bat from 10,000 to 40,000 years should be long enongh to establish a Character for m pescable disposition, and it is quite that time since anything reported before against the Poy. Still there are thermal springs aboat, and mon who have felt its pulse say that geo- thermic force increases. So that, thoagh not exactly probabilities, there are possibilities. 'The Puy's best hope of escape bas been i's distance from the sea.

div.head: LETTER 70 THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves reaponatbie for the optnions ex- f | pressed by our correepondenta, but we wish, in a epiit uf | fair play'to all, to permit within certain necessary Menite—~ ] | free discussion:
A SELF-INDICTMENT.

d| To Tux Borror or tue "Bayrrian Gagerre." *| Sir,—In days like these when time is very | highly valded, it is well to note how Egypt: # | inne waste their time. : We find them spending the best part of the t|day in oafér, doing nothing bot chativring, g | looking at the passers-by, eto, and if reading, they read the vernacular papers, whioh still: d | ignore the fact that the Press is » great edaca- f | tional force and pablishes inflammatory n | articles, : . 1] If you call at the cafés at any time of the | day, you will find bondreds 'and handreds n| with no work to do, If they are from the . | low class, they will be general disturbers of other's peace and serenity, and if from higher classes, they will take no thought -of the value of time. The reason is, perbaps, the existence of so many cafés in every quarter of every town. Previously it was very easy to 'allow any spplicant to establish a café, bat the Govern- ment would do better now to refase such permission. "+

s| In theschools it is advisable to teach the || popils the valae of time, and to break, the present common habit of frequenting the oaféa, as they often lead them to neglect their atadies.—I remain yours, respectfally Aw Eoyrriay.
Medinet el Fayoom, 18th September.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
